info.game_comments: Game in which 63 correct responses were given (with three rebounds).

(1, 1).clue: The baluchitherium, an extinct type of this pachyderm, had no horn, unlike modern species

(2, 1).clue: Aaron Spelling's daughter Tori plays Donna Martin on this popular TV series

(3, 1).clue: A box of 64 Crayola crayons has one of these devices "built-in"

(4, 1).clue: In October 1971 Taiwan was expelled from this organization & Red China was admitted

(5, 1).clue: After a family meal, you may fold this item & place it back inside its ring

(6, 1).clue: Something that turns out well "comes up smelling like" these flowers

(1, 2).clue: The dodo was found on the Islands of Reunion, Rodrigues & Mauritius in this ocean

(2, 2).clue: When this singer starred in a revival of "Funny Girl", one critic said, "Pia doesn't fall on her fanny"

(3, 2).clue: In 1835 C.S.A. Thilorier froze this gas to create the first "dry ice"

(4, 2).clue: During Japanese control of Taiwan, this largest city was called Taihoku

(5, 2).clue: The most formal evening wear is this color "tie", but black tie is much more popular

(6, 2).clue: Because artists tend to flatter their models, a fine-looking female is said to be "as pretty as" this

(1, 3).clue: The last known representative of this type of pigeon died in the Cincinnati Zoo in 1914

(2, 3).clue: Patrick Stewart wrote & starred in a one-man show based on this Dickens Christmas classic

(3, 3).clue: After hearing this invention of his work, Edison said, "I was never so taken aback in my life"

(4, 3).clue: His birthday is observed as a holiday on October 31

(5, 3).clue: Some small wedding receptions eliminate this greeting line that was once de rigeueur
(5, 3).correct response: the receiving line (the reception line accepted)

(6, 3).clue: A fine voice is "as clear as" one of these tintinnabulating objects

(1, 4).clue: Steller's Sea Cow was a relative of this rare aquatic mammal found in Florida

(2, 4).clue: This British actress played Isadora Duncan on film in 1968 & onstage in 1991

(3, 4).clue: C. Vanderbilt thought George Westinghouse's idea of stopping a train by this means a fool notion

(4, 4).clue: It is prohibited to bring literature promoting this ideology into Taiwan

(5, 4).clue: Black ribbon streamers on a family's front door were once a sign of this

(6, 4).clue: A really fast person runs like this kind of "lightning"—as if regular lightning isn't fast enough

(1, 5).clue: The name of this extinct elephant-like creature comes from Greek meaning "breast tooth"

(2, 5).clue: Playwright who made his film debut in "Renaldo and Clara" in 1978 & won a Pulitzer Prize for Drama in '79

(3, 5).clue: First built in 1960, it's also been called an optical maser

(4, 5).clue: Mariners from this country named Taiwan Ilha Formosa, but didn't colonize it

(5, 5).clue: In 1922 Emily Post wrote, "A gentleman takes off" this "when a lady enters the elevator"

(6, 5).clue: A person who's out of his element is "like a fish" in this predicament

(1, 1).clue: In 1991 B.C. Amenemhet, a former vizier, founded this country's 12th dynasty

(2, 1).clue: "Homage to the Queen", a tribute to her, premiered on her coronation day in 1953

(3, 1).clue: Unlike most birds, ratites like the ostrich can't do this

(4, 1).clue: The summer varieties of this gourd-like vegetable are eaten green; the winter ones, ripe

(5, 1).clue: In 1777 Chief Joseph Brant led his fellow Mohawks in the Battle of Oriskany during this war

(6, 1).clue: This novelist's youthful voyages provided the basis for such works as "Lord Jim" & "Typhoon"

(1, 2).clue: Because his proposals for constitutional change were defeated, this French president resigned in 1969

(2, 2).clue: This dancer choreographed a new version of "The Nutcracker" in 1976, a "Turning Point" in his career

(3, 2).clue: Associated with this sense, the olfactory lobe is better developed in most vertebrates than in man

(4, 2).clue: This fruit with many seeds is grown on the Punica granatum tree

(5, 2).clue: A woman claiming to be this Lewis & Clark companion died in 1884; she would have been about 100

(6, 2).clue: He dictated his last novel, "The Brothers Karamazov", to his wife who took it down in shorthand

(1, 3).clue: In 1919 this national assembly met in this city & formed a new German republic

(2, 3).clue: The School of American Ballet is the official school of this major metropolitan ballet company

(3, 3).clue: Renin, an enzyme that breaks down protein, is secreted by cells in this organ

(4, 3).clue: Poi, a luau treat, is made from these mashed roots

(5, 3).clue: Geronimo rode in this U.S. president's 1905 inaugural parade

(6, 3).clue: This Scottish novelist is buried at the summit of Mt. Vaea on Upolu, an island of Western Samoa

(1, 4).clue: The parents of this Peruvian president immigrated from Japan 4 years prior to his birth

(2, 4).clue: This Spanish seducer is attacked by furies at the end of a 1936 ballet

(3, 4).clue: Common "colorful" term for the eythrocytes, which transport oxygen around the body

(4, 4).clue: A greengage is a plum & a greening is this fruit

(5, 4).clue: When this chief, Pocahontas' father, died in 1618, he was succeeded by his brother Opitchapam

(6, 4).clue: This novelist's nonfiction book "Miami and the Siege of Chicago" was about the 1968 political conventions

(1, 5).clue: About 3000 B.S. the Sumerians invented this writing system which used triangular marks

(2, 5).clue: First performed in 1905, this very short solo ballet depicts the last minutes in the life of a bird

(3, 5).clue: This nucleic acid occurs in 3 forms: messenger, ribosomal & transfer

(4, 5).clue: This somewhat coarse root vegetable is also called a swede or a Swedish turnip

(5, 5).clue: This chief once called "The Apache Napoleon" died in the Arizona territory in 1874

(6, 5).clue: He followed his first novel, "Appointment in Samarra", with "BUtterfield 8"

(0, 0).clue: The name of this river, famous in song, may be a corruption of the Spanish for "little Saint John"
